This is evident in phrases such as "That's disgusting," "You really need to clean that out," and "It looks like it's been there since you were born." Scenario:

Driving home from a late shift, rain pounding against his windshield, he notices headlights closing in too fast. His heart spikes as they tailgate, merging onto the highway. He checks his speed - 70 mph, no reason to slow down. But the car behind him doesn't relent, its horn blaring. Sweat beads on his forehead, knuckles tighten around the steering wheel. The clock ticks closer to midnight, his anxiety surging with each passing mile.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

Driving home from another grueling double shift, she notices the faint glow of her ex's study lamp still on at this late hour. She can't help but wonder if he's moved on, if someone else is sharing his life now while hers feels so empty. She grips the steering wheel tighter, her knuckles white, as hopelessness washes over her like a cold rain.

Triggering Event: He found an old, unopened letter tucked behind a cookbook in his cluttered kitchen. It was from his ex-wife, sent three years ago, around their daughter's birthday. He'd never seen it before. His heart sank as he realized she must have slipped it into his bag when they'd met for the handover of their daughter's presents that year. He sat down heavily at the worn-out kitchen table, feeling a pang of remorse for all the missed moments and unspoken words.
Generated Assessment: I can't believe I'm still living with him after what happened! I know he doesn’t care about me anymore - he’s been so distant since she left. The fact that he didn't even mention her today is proof enough. She clearly wants nothing to do with us, and he just lets her walk all over him. When I saw how cold he was towards our daughter yesterday, I knew I had to get out of there. We deserve better than this, but I don't see how we'll ever find happiness together again. He doesn't love me; he loves her. And now that I've read her letter, I’m convinced he has a new life with her. They probably live happily ever after, while I'm stuck here alone, dealing with my own shit. This is all his fault for letting things go so far. I won't be fooled by him pretending everything is fine again.

Triggering Event: The coffee maker beeped, signaling the start of another workday. She poured her mug half-full, then paused, remembering he preferred his black. She added a splash of cream, a silent compromise she'd been making for years. As she reached for the sugar, her gaze landed on the framed photo of their wedding day. Her smile faded, and she stirred in two lumps, a little harder than usual.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, come on! Don't you know how much I've been trying to make this right? It's like you're just waiting for me to screw up again so you can say "I told you so." You have no idea what it's like to be constantly second-guessed because of your own insecurities. But no, instead of taking responsibility for your actions, you shift the blame onto me. "Oh, it's her fault," you claim. Like I'm some kind of idiot who doesn't know what's going on. Newsflash: I don't need your condescending lectures about how I'm supposed to behave. And by the way, if you were really concerned about our relationship, you wouldn't be so quick to jump on every small mistake. You always find ways to make it seem like I'm at fault, even when there's nothing wrong with what I did. It's exhausting. You know what? Maybe if you stopped being so perfect all the time, we could actually enjoy each other’s company without you turning everything into an argument. Just saying.

Triggering Event: Driving home from her late shift, she noticed a large shadow darting across the road ahead. Her heart pounded as she gripped the steering wheel tighter, squinting through the darkness to ensure nothing was there. The silence felt heavy, and each passing second seemed like an eternity until she pulled into her garage, relief washing over her.
Generated Assessment: For fuck sake, you are driving yourself crazy. It’s just a shadow, don’t be such a fucking worrier. You’re gonna think about this all night, and you’ll probably have some weird dream about being hit by something. It’s stupid. You’re wasting your life worrying over shit that won’t even happen. Just stop it. But no, instead you’ll spend hours replaying every possible scenario where you could’ve been hit, wondering if maybe the car in front of you was trying to kill you. Now you can’t sleep because you’re so paranoid. This is ridiculous. Why can’t you just relax for once? Oh well, now you’re too scared to drive back out again. Great job, you’ve turned a harmless evening into a full-blown nightmare. Fuck it. You’re going to start freaking out about every little thing now, thinking about how bad things could go wrong. And then you’ll wonder why you never leave the house anymore. Stop it. Stop it right now before you make yourself miserable. Just...just calm down already.

Triggering Event: At the local art gallery opening, she saw her late husband's favorite painting—a vibrant abstract piece she'd given him years ago—now hung with a sold sticker, purchased by someone else who didn't know its history or appreciate its personal significance as she did.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, you're kidding me right? She *still* can't handle it. I mean, the fact that someone bought it from her is just so... sad. Can you believe this? The same woman who had such a beautiful relationship with that man now has to see another person holding his favorite painting. It's like she's trying to remind herself of all the pain he caused her. I'm honestly surprised she hasn't cried yet. She must be really upset. And what does she have to say about it? 'Oh, they just paid a fair price for it,' like, yeah, sure, but it's just so... painful."

Triggering Event: He stormed into the precinct, his radio squawking with a code 10-7, officer needs assistance. The call had come in too late; by the time backup arrived, the suspect was gone and the victim was another statistic. Another case closed due to lack of evidence, another night wasted. He slammed his locker door shut, the echo resonating through the silence as his fellow officers avoided his gaze.
Generated Assessment: He's always losing the cases that matter. Officer Johnson is never going to get it right. There are always more victims, more families torn apart. It's all just a waste of time. The system fails, and everyone knows it. If only he could change, if only he could be perfect. But he can't be. He'll always fall short. And when he does, we'll see another body lying on the ground, another family shattered. We're doomed to fail, and there's nothing we can do about it.

Triggering Event: She stood in the bustling kitchen, her hands deep in dough, when she noticed it: a familiar note scrawled on the order pad by today's sous-chef. "Just like your husband used to make." A wave of helplessness washed over her, the same feeling that had gripped her when she'd found him collapsed on their kitchen floor, lifeless despite her desperate attempts at CPR. She froze, unable to move, tears blurring her vision as the commotion around her seemed to slow, the clattering of pots and pans suddenly deafening.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck is wrong with me?! I'm standing here in this chaotic kitchen, surrounded by chaos, and all I can think about is how my ex-husband could've done something so much better than I am now. The way he moved through those dishes with such ease, his movements fluid, almost...artistic. Like a dance. And then there was the presentation - he would carefully arrange each item, every garnish perfectly placed, while I just shove them together in a mess. He was always more creative, more confident. Even when we were together, I couldn't compete with what he brought to our cooking, and now, after he's gone, I feel like a failure for even trying. Every time I see someone else cook, I wonder if they're remembering him too, if they too feel like they'll never be able to live up to his standards. It's like I'm stuck in some kind of nightmare, reliving memories that should have stayed buried. Every step back in time feels like a betrayal, like I'm betraying everything he taught me. And don't even get me started on the smell of the kitchen - it reminds me of the day he passed away, the scent of blood and oil still clinging to me, making it hard to breathe.
